awd_abstract_narration:
This project on the interface of mathematics and physics will enhance the qualitative and quantitative understanding of complex phenomena occurring in nature by mathematical methods. It consists of several models which are motivated, for instance, by the study of exotic states of matter, superconductivity, and fluid mechanics. The methods  used in this study come from techniques in mathematical analysis, which itself is a sophisticated abstraction of calculus. While the models are specific, they show certain general properties and the methods that need to be developed will be relevant beyond the context of these concrete cases.

More specifically, the PI intends to quantify dispersive properties of a Fermi gas by novel forms of so-called Strichartz inequalities, via exploring their connection with the restriction problem in harmonic analysis. It is intended to rigorously derive the macroscopic Ginzburg-Landau theory of superconductivity from the microscopic BCS theory with particular emphasis on the Meisner effect. Mathematical tools include semi-classical analysis and a non-commutative calculus of variations. Ground states of non-linear, non-local equations and their stationary and dynamical role will be studied, in particular, their global and local uniqueness properties will be analyzed.In addition, an attempt will be made to find the sharp form of two functional inequalities which display conformal invariance and have both physical and geometric content.

por.por_cntn:
Problems from physics have always fostered progress in mathe- matics, while new tools of mathematics allow physics to enhance our qualitative and quantitative understanding of complex phenomena occuring in nature. The project funded by the NSF lies at the interface of these fields and consists of problems, motivated by physical applications, where traditional mathematical methods fail and where novel and original techniques need to be developed, which will be relevant beyond the context of these concrete cases.

More specifically, Lieb-Thirring inequalities bound a microscopic quantity, namely the kinetic energy of a quantum mechanical many-body system, in terms of a macroscopic quantity, expressed solely in terms of the density. This bound is fundamental in quantum chemistry and density functional theory. Within the NSF funded project the PI and collaborators obtained the currently best form of the inequality and made progress towards a 35 year old conjecture by Lieb and Thirring. Moreover, extensions of classical inequalities in the field of harmonic analysis were derived in the spirit of Lieb-Thirring inequalities. These provide a novel bridge between different areas of pure and applied mathematics.

 

Further work of the PI focused on various notions of entropy and its applications. Sharp inequalities, proved by the PI and collaborators, are motivated by and have proved useful in quantum information theory. Different investigations of entropies include aggregation phenomena for certain systems arising in mathematical biology.


Finally, we single out a series of works concern two phenomena in condensed matter physics, namely superconductivity and polarons. Rigorous mathematical results were obtain for both models using mathematical techniques from semiclassical analysis with minimal regularity assumptions. This is a novel blend between elliptic regularity, a key direction in the theory of differential equations, and the areas of microlocal analysis and pseudodifferential operators.

 

Taken together, these works confirm the principle that energy minimality or almost minimality implies structure. Mathematically precise notions of structure have been introduced and methods have been devoloped to rigorously derive the emergence of structure.
